V. Dortmund''', commonly known as '''Borussia Dortmund''' ({{IPA-de|boˈʁʊsi̯aː ˈdɔɐ̯tmʊnt|-|De-Borussia Dortmund.ogg}}),{{Citation |last=Mangold |first=Max|year=2005 |title=Das Aussprachewörterbuch|publisher=Duden |isbn=978-3-411-04066-7|pages=212 and 282}} '''BVB''' ({{IPA-de|beːfaʊ̯ˈbeː|pron|De-BVB.ogg}}), or simply '''Dortmund''' ({{IPA-de|ˈdɔʁtmʊnt|pron|De-Dortmund2.ogg}}), is a German professional [[sports club]] based in [[Dortmund]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. It is best known for its men's professional [[football club (association football)|football]] team, which plays in the [[Bundesliga]], the top tier of the [[German football league system]]. The club have won eight [[List of German football champions|league championships]], five [[DFB-Pokal]]s, one [[UEFA Champions League]], one [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]], and one [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]]. Founded in 1909 by eighteen football players from Dortmund, the football team is part of a large membership-based sports club with more than 145,000 members,{{cite web|url=http://www.bvb.de/eng/News/Overview/The-fourth-biggest-club-in-the-world| title = The fourth biggest club in the world | publisher = bvb.de | date = 28 November 2016 | access-date = 29 November 2016}} making Borussia Dortmund the second largest sports club by membership in Germany. The club has active departments in other sports, namely in [[Borussia Dortmund Handball|women's handball]]. Since 1974, Dortmund have played their home games at [[Westfalenstadion]]; the stadium is the largest in Germany, and Dortmund has the highest average attendance of any [[Football club (association football)|association football club]] in the world.{{Cite web|url=https://talksport.com/football/525568/top-50-average-football-attendances-in-the-world-in-the-last-five-years-including-manchester-united-barcelona-and-borussia-dortmund/|title=The top 50 average attendances in football over the last five years|date=12 April 2019}} Borussia Dortmund's colours are black and yellow, giving the club its nickname ''die Schwarzgelben''.{{cite web |url= http://www.puma.com/football/teams/42-borussia-dortmund |title= Borussia Dortmund – Puma SE |work= puma.com |publisher= [[Puma SE]] |access-date= 17 August 2013 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140113053901/http://www.puma.com/football/teams/42-borussia-dortmund# |archive-date= 13 January 2014 |url-status=dead |df= dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/teamsandplayers/teams/club=52758/profile/index.html|title= Borussia Dortmund|publisher = [[UEFA]] |access-date = 17 August 2013}} They hold a long-standing rivalry with [[Ruhr]] neighbours [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]], with whom they contest the [[Revierderby]]. They also contest [[Der Klassiker]] with [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. In terms of [[Deloitte]]'s annual [[Deloitte Football Money League|Football Money League]], Dortmund was in 2021 ranked as the second richest sports club in Germany, and the 12th richest football team in the world.{{cite web| title = Deloitte Football Money League 2022 (rankings for the 2020–21 season)| url = https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/uk/Documents/sports-business-group/deloitte-uk-dfml22.pdf | website = www2.deloitte.com }} Moreover, under the directorship of [[Michael Zorc]] in the 2010s, Dortmund have cultivated a reputation for spotting and developing young talent, and have remained focused on developing a [[youth system]].{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/why-borussia-dortmund-not-so-secret-recipe-for-success-so-hard-to-copy-a4110971.html|title= Why Borussia Dortmund's not-so-secret recipe for success is so hard to copy|date= 6 April 2019|publisher=Standard|access-date=3 February 2020}} They have also received plaudits for generally adhering to an attacking footballing philosophy.{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.co.uk/football/german-bundesliga/10/blog/post/3753198/borussia-dortmund-stopped-spending-and-started-scouting-now-theyre-top-of-the-bundesliga|title=Borussia Dortmund stopped spending and started scouting. Now they're top of the Bundesliga|date=17 January 2019|publisher=ESPN|access-date=3 February 2020}} ==History== ===Foundation and early years=== [[File:Borussia dortmund 1913.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|Borussia Dortmund in 1913]] The club was founded on 19 December 1909 by a group of young men unhappy with the Catholic church-sponsored ''Trinity Youth'', where they played football under the stern and unsympathetic eye of the local parish priest. The priest, Father Dewald was blocked at the door when he tried to break up the organising meeting being held in a room of the local pub, ''Zum Wildschütz''. The founders were Franz and Paul Braun, Henry Cleve, Hans Debest, Paul Dziendzielle, Franz, Julius and Wilhelm Jacobi, Hans Kahn, Gustav Müller, Franz Risse, Fritz Schulte, Hans Siebold, August Tönnesmann, Heinrich and Robert Unger, Fritz Weber and Franz Wendt. The name ''Borussia'' is [[Latin]] for [[Prussia]] but was taken from Borussia beer from the nearby Borussia brewery in Dortmund.{{cite web| url=http://www.bvb.de/eng/BVB/History/1909| title=A turbulent founding on 19/12/1909| website=BVB Club Website| access-date=9 August 2014}} The team began playing in blue and white striped shirts with a red sash, and black shorts. In 1913, they donned the black and yellow stripes so familiar today. Over the next decades the club enjoyed only modest success playing in local leagues. They had a brush with bankruptcy in 1929 when an attempt to boost the club's fortunes by signing some paid professional footballers failed miserably and left the team deep in debt. They survived only through the generosity of a local supporter who covered the team's shortfall out of his own pocket. The 1930s saw the rise of the [[Third Reich]], which restructured sports and football organisations throughout the nation to suit the regime's goals. ''Borussia'''s president was replaced when he refused to join the [[Nazi Party]], and a couple of members who surreptitiously used the club's offices to produce anti-Nazi pamphlets were executed in the last days of the war. The club did have greater success in the newly established [[Gauliga Westfalen]], but would have to wait until after [[World War II]] to make a breakthrough. It was during this time that Borussia developed its intense rivalry with [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] of suburban [[Gelsenkirchen]], the most successful side of the era (see ''[[Revierderby]]''). Like every other organisation in Germany, Borussia was dissolved by the Allied occupation authorities after the war in an attempt to distance the country's institutions from its so-recent Nazi past. There was a short-lived attempt to merge the club with two others – ''Werksportgemeinschaft Hoesch'' and ''Freier Sportverein 98'' – as ''Sportgemeinschaft Borussia von 1898'', but it was as ''Ballspiel-Verein Borussia'' (''BVB'') that they made their first appearance in the national league final in 1949, where they lost 2–3 to [[VfR Mannheim]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2014}} ===First national titles=== [[File:Borussia Dortmund Performance Chart.png|450px|thumb|Historical chart of Borussia Dortmund league performance]] Between 1946 and 1963, Borussia featured in the [[Oberliga West (1947–63)|Oberliga West]], a first division league which dominated German football through the late 1950s. In [[1949 German football championship|1949]], Borussia reached the [[1949 German football championship#Final|final]] in [[Stuttgart]] against [[VfR Mannheim]], which they lost 2–3 after extra time. The club claimed its first national title in [[1956 German football championship|1956]] with a 4–2 win against [[Karlsruher SC]]. One year later, Borussia defeated [[Hamburger SV]] 4–1 to win their [[1957 German football championship|second national title]]. After this coup, the three Alfredos ([[Alfred Preißler]], [[Alfred Kelbassa]] and [[Alfred Niepieklo]]) were legends in Dortmund. In [[1963 German football championship|1963]], Borussia won the last edition of the [[List of German football champions#German football championships Postwar to the Bundesliga (1946–63)|German Football Championship]] (before the introduction of the new [[Bundesliga]]) to secure their third national title. ===Bundesliga debut=== In 1962, the [[German Football Association|DFB]] met in Dortmund and voted to establish a professional football league in Germany, to begin play in August 1963 as the [[Bundesliga]]. Borussia Dortmund earned its place among the first sixteen clubs to play in the league by winning the last pre-Bundesliga national championship. Runners-up [[1. FC Köln]] also earned an automatic berth. Dortmund's [[Friedhelm Konietzka]] scored the first-ever Bundesliga goal a minute into the match, which they would eventually lose 2–3 to [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]]. In [[1964–65 DFB-Pokal|1965]], Dortmund captured its first [[DFB-Pokal]]. In 1966, Dortmund won the [[1965–66 European Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup]] 2–1 against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in extra time, with the goals coming from [[Sigfried Held]] and [[Reinhard Libuda]]. In the same year, however, the team surrendered a commanding position atop the [[1965–66 Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] by losing four of their last five league games and finishing second, three points behind champions [[TSV 1860 München|1860 München]]. Ironically, much of 1860 München's success came on the strength of the play of Konietzka, recently transferred from Dortmund. The 1970s were characterised by financial problems, relegation from the Bundesliga in 1972, and the opening of the [[Westfalenstadion]], named after its home region [[Westphalia]] in 1974. The club earned its return to Bundesliga in 1976. Dortmund continued to have financial problems through the 1980s. ''BVB'' avoided being relegated in 1986 by winning a third decisive playoff game against [[SC Fortuna Köln|Fortuna Köln]] after finishing the regular season in 16th place. Dortmund did not enjoy any significant success again until a 4–1 DFB-Pokal win in [[1988–89 DFB-Pokal|1989]] against Werder Bremen. It was [[Horst Köppel]]'s first trophy as a manager. Dortmund then won the [[1989 DFB-Supercup|1989 DFL-Supercup]] 4–3 against rivals [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. ===Golden age – the 1990s=== After a tenth-place finish in the Bundesliga in [[1990–91 Bundesliga|1991]], manager [[Horst Köppel]] was let go and manager [[Ottmar Hitzfeld]] was hired. In [[1991–92 Bundesliga|1992]], Hitzfeld led Borussia Dortmund to a second-place finish in the Bundesliga and would have won the title had [[VfB Stuttgart]] not won their last game to become champions instead. Along with a fourth-place finish in the Bundesliga, Dortmund made it to the 1993 [[1992–93 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]] [[1993 UEFA Cup Final|final]], which they lost 6–1 on aggregate to [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]]. In spite of this result, Borussia walked away with [[Deutsche Mark|DM]]25 million under the prize money pool system in place at the time for German sides participating in the Cup. Cash flush, Dortmund was able to sign players who later brought them numerous honours in the 1990s. Under the [[Captain (association football)|captaincy]] of 1996 [[Ballon d'Or|European Footballer of the Year]] [[Matthias Sammer]], Borussia Dortmund won back-to-back Bundesliga titles in [[1994–95 Bundesliga|1995]] and [[1995–96 Bundesliga|1996]]. Dortmund also won the [[DFL-Supercup]] against [[Borussia Mönchengladbach|Mönchengladbach]] in [[1995 DFB-Supercup|1995]] and [[1. FC Kaiserslautern]] in [[1996 DFB-Supercup|1996]]. In [[1996–97 UEFA Champions League|1996–97]] the team reached its first [[List of European Cup and UEFA Champions League finals|European Cup final]]. In a memorable [[1997 UEFA Champions League Final|match]] at the [[Olympic Stadium (Munich)|Olympiastadion]] in [[Munich]], Dortmund faced the holders Juventus. [[Karl-Heinz Riedle]] put Dortmund ahead, shooting under goalkeeper [[Angelo Peruzzi]] from a cross by [[Paul Lambert]]. Riedle then made it two with a bullet header from a corner kick. In the second half, [[Alessandro Del Piero]] pulled one back for Juventus with a back heel. Then 20-year-old substitute and local boy [[Lars Ricken]] latched onto a through pass by [[Andreas Möller]]. Only 16 seconds after coming on to the pitch, Ricken chipped Peruzzi in the Juventus goal from over 20 yards out with his first touch of the ball. With [[Zinedine Zidane]] unable to make an impression for Juventus against the close marking of Lambert,{{cite web|url=http://www.espnstar.com/rss-feed/detail/item617249/ |title=Paul Lambert – The Norwich wizard |date=4 May 2011 |publisher=ESPN |access-date=28 November 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223063347/http://www.espnstar.com/rss-feed/detail/item617249/ |archive-date=23 December 2011 }}{{cite news | url = http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/english-football/norwich-city-manager-paul-lambert-on-his-vision-for-the-future-1.917708 | title = Norwich City manager Paul Lambert on his vision for the future | work = Sunday Herald | date = 6 September 2009 | access-date =28 November 2011}}{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2011/nov/25/joy-of-six-football-exports | title = Revealed: The Joy of Six: British and Irish footballers abroad | work = The Guardian | location=London | date = 25 November 2011| access-date =28 November 2011}} Dortmund lifted the trophy with a 3–1 victory. Dortmund then went on to beat Brazilian club [[Cruzeiro Esporte Clube|Cruzeiro]] 2–0 in the [[1997 Intercontinental Cup]] Final to become world club champions.{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablest/toyota97.html |title=Intercontinental Club Cup 1997 |first = Marcelo |last = Leme de Arruda |publisher = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]] |date = 2 August 1999 |access-date = 7 May 2012}} Borussia Dortmund were the second German club to win the Intercontinental Cup, after Bayern Munich in [[1976 Intercontinental Cup|1976]].{{cite web |url=http://www.theoriginalwinger.com/2013-04-23-borussia-dortmund-v-real-madrid-champions-league-preview|title= Borussia Dortmund v Real Madrid – Champions League Preview |work= theoriginalwinger.com |date =23 April 2013|access-date = 17 August 2013}} As defending champions Dortmund reached the Champions League semi-final in 1998. The team was missing key players from the start of the season when they played [[Real Madrid]] in the '98 semi. Sammer's career was cut short by injury and only played three first team games after the Champions League win. Lambert had left in November to return to play in Scotland. Möller missed the first leg as did Kohler who missed both games in the tie. Real won the first leg 2–0 at home. Dortmund played better in the second leg but failed to take their chances. Dortmund went out 2–0 on aggregate.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=1942584.html|title=Chapuisat: Dortmund v Madrid will be 'incredible'|publisher=UEFA|date=22 April 2013}} ===21st century and Borussia "goes public"=== [[File:Borussia Dortmund Team 2007 08.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|Borussia Dortmund in 2007]] In October 2000, Borussia Dortmund became the first publicly traded club on the German stock market.{{cite news |title=Borussia Dortmund fans and investors aren't on the same team |url=https://www.dw.com/en/borussia-dortmund-fans-and-investors-arent-on-the-same-team/a-15074555-1 |access-date=12 July 2018 |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=13 May 2011}} In [[2001–02 Bundesliga|2002]], Borussia Dortmund won their third Bundesliga title. Dortmund had a remarkable run at the end of the season to overtake [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen|Bayer Leverkusen]], securing the title on the final day. Manager [[Matthias Sammer]] became the first person in Borussia Dortmund history to win the Bundesliga as both a player and manager.{{cite web |url=http://www.indiatoday.intoday.in/story/champions-league-final-2013-bayern-munich-vs-borussia-dortmund-match-preview-facts-key-players/1/272818.html|title= Bayern Munich vs Borussia Dortmund: The first all-German Champions League final |work=India Today |date =24 May 2013|access-date = 17 August 2013}} In the same season, Borussia lost the [[2002 UEFA Cup Final|final]] of the [[2001–02 UEFA Cup]] to Dutch side [[Feyenoord]]. Dortmund's fortunes then steadily declined for a number of years. Poor financial management led to a heavy debt load and the sale of their Westfalenstadion grounds. The situation was compounded by failure to advance in the [[2003–04 UEFA Champions League]], when the team was eliminated on penalties in the qualifying rounds by [[Club Brugge KV|Club Brugge]]. In 2003, Bayern Munich loaned €2 million to Dortmund for several months to pay their payroll. Borussia was again driven to the brink of [[bankruptcy]] in 2005, the original €11 value of its shares having plummeted by over 80% on the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]]. At this time [[Hans-Joachim Watzke]] was appointed CEO and streamlined the club. The response to the crisis included a 20% pay cut for all players.{{cite web|author=Von abendblatt.de |url=http://www.abendblatt.de/sport/fussball/article2179798/Hoeness-plaudert-Haben-BVB-zwei-Millionen-Euro-geliehen.html |title=Pikantes Geheimnis – Hoeneß plaudert: "Haben BVB zwei Millionen Euro geliehen" – Sport – Fußball – Hamburger Abendblatt |date=6 February 2012 |publisher=Abendblatt.de |language=de |access-date=5 March 2013}} In 2006, in order to reduce debt, the [[Westfalenstadion]] was renamed "Signal Iduna Park" after a local insurance company. The naming rights agreement runs until 2021. Dortmund suffered a miserable start to the [[2005–06 Bundesliga|2005–06]] season, but rallied to finish seventh. The club failed to gain a place in the [[2006–07 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]] via the Fair Play draw. The club's management recently indicated that the club again showed a profit; this was largely related to the sale of [[David Odonkor]] to [[Real Betis]] and [[Tomáš Rosický]] to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. In the [[2006–07 Bundesliga|2006–07]] season, Dortmund unexpectedly faced serious [[Promotion and relegation|relegation]] trouble for the first time in years. Dortmund went through three coaches and appointed [[Thomas Doll]] on 13 March 2007 after dropping to just one point above the relegation zone. [[Christoph Metzelder]] also left Borussia Dortmund on a free transfer. In the [[2007–08 Bundesliga|2007–08]] season, Dortmund lost to many smaller [[Bundesliga]] clubs. Despite finishing 13th in the Bundesliga table, Dortmund reached the [[2007–08 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]] Final against Bayern Munich, where they lost 2–1 in extra time. The final appearance qualified Dortmund for the [[2008–09 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]] because Bayern already qualified for the [[2008–09 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]]. Thomas Doll resigned on 19 May 2008 and was replaced by [[Jürgen Klopp]]. ===Return to prominence=== [[File:Championship celebration Borussia Dortmund 2011.jpg|thumb|right|Borussia Dortmund players celebrate winning the Bundesliga in [[2010–11 Bundesliga|2011]]]] In the [[2009–10 Bundesliga|2009–10]] season, Klopp's Dortmund improved on the season before finishing fifth in the Bundesliga to qualify for the [[2010–11 UEFA Europa League|UEFA Europa League]]. The team missed an opportunity to qualify for the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] by failing to beat eighth-place [[VfL Wolfsburg]] and 14th-place [[SC Freiburg]] in the final two matches of the campaign. Entering the [[2010–11 Bundesliga|2010–11]] season, Dortmund fielded a young and vibrant roster. On 4 December 2010, Borussia became ''[[Herbstmeister]]'' ("Autumn Champion"), an unofficial accolade going to the league leader at the winter break. They did this three matches before the break, sharing the record for having achieved this earliest with [[Eintracht Frankfurt]] (1993–94) and 1. FC Kaiserslautern (1997–98).{{cite web |url=http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/bundesliga1/bundesliga-dortmund-vorzeitig-bundesliga-herbstmeister_aid_578667.html |title=Dortmund vorzeitig Bundesliga-Herbstmeister |author=sid |date=4 December 2010 |publisher=[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus]] online |language=de |access-date=5 December 2010}} On 30 April 2011, the club beat [[1. FC Nürnberg]] 2–0 at home, while second-place Bayer Leverkusen lost, leaving Dortmund eight points clear with two games to play. This championship equalled the seven national titles held by rivals Schalke 04, and guaranteed a spot in the [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League|2011–12 Champions League]] group stages.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/feedarticle/9622741 |title=Borussia Dortmund wrap up Bundesliga title |date=30 April 2011 |work=The Guardian |access-date=1 May 2011 }} One year later, Dortmund made a successful defence of its Bundesliga title with a win over [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]], again on the 32nd match day. By the 34th and final match day, Dortmund set a new record with the most points—81—ever gained by a club in one Bundesliga season.{{cite web |url=http://sportbild.bild.de/SPORT/bundesliga/2012/05/05/dortmund-freiburg/bvb-knackt-punkterekord.html |title=81 Punkte! BVB bester Meister aller Zeiten |date=5 May 2012 |publisher=SportBild.de |language=de |trans-title=81 Points! BVB is the best Champion of all Time |access-date=12 May 2012}}{{cite news |url=https://www.welt.de/sport/fussball/bundesliga/borussia-dortmund/article106262721/Dortmund-der-beste-Deutsche-Meister-aller-Zeiten.html |title=Dortmund, der beste Deutsche Meister aller Zeiten |date=5 May 2012 |newspaper=Die Welt |language=de |trans-title=Dortmund, the best German Champion of all Time |access-date=12 May 2012}} This was surpassed the following season by Bayern Munich's 91 points.{{cite news|title=Super Bayern rewrite the history books|url=http://www.fcbayern.telekom.de/en/news/news/2013/42504.php|access-date=18 May 2013|newspaper=Bayern Munich|date=18 May 2013}} The club's eighth championship places it third in [[List of German football champions#Total German football championships won|total national titles]], and players will now wear [[Verdiente Meistervereine|two stars]] over their uniform crest in recognition of the team's five Bundesliga titles. Notable names from the winning roster include [[Lucas Barrios]], [[Mario Götze]], [[Neven Subotić]], [[Mats Hummels]], [[Robert Lewandowski]], [[Shinji Kagawa]], [[Łukasz Piszczek]], [[Jakub Błaszczykowski]], [[Kevin Großkreutz]], [[Ivan Perišić]] and [[İlkay Gündoğan]]. The club capped its successful 2011–12 season by winning the [[double (association football)|double]] for the first time by beating Bayern 5–2 in the [[2012 DFB-Pokal Final|final]] of the [[2011–12 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]]. Borussia Dortmund are one of four German clubs to win the Bundesliga and DFB-Pokal [[Double (association football)|double]], along with Bayern Munich, [[1. FC Köln]] and [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]].{{cite web |url=http://www.rp-online.de/sport/fussball/bundesliga/die-double-gewinner-des-deutschen-fussballs-1.2803420 |title=Die Double-Gewinner des deutschen Fussballs |date=13 May 2012 |publisher=rp.online |language=de |trans-title=The double-winners of German football |access-date=26 April 2013}} The club was voted Team of the Year 2011 at the annual ''Sportler des Jahres'' (German Sports Personality of the Year) awards. [[File:BVB-Fans in Wembley.jpg|thumb|right|Borussia Dortmund fans at [[Wembley Stadium]] during the [[2013 UEFA Champions League Final|2013 Champions League Final]]]] Borussia Dortmund ended the [[2012–13 Borussia Dortmund season|2012–13 season]] in second place in the [[2012–13 Bundesliga|Bundesliga]]. Dortmund played in their second [[2013 UEFA Champions League Final|UEFA Champions League Final]] against Bayern Munich in the first ever all-German club final at [[Wembley Stadium]] on 25 May 2013, which they lost 2–1.{{cite web | url = http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000351/match=2009612/prematch/player-lists/index.html| title =UEFA Champions League 2013 – Dortmund-Bayern Players – UEFA}} In the [[2013–14 Borussia Dortmund season|2013–14 season]], Borussia Dortmund won the [[2013 DFL-Supercup]] 4–2 against rivals Bayern Munich.{{cite web|title=Dortmund prevail over Bayern in Supercup thriller|url=http://www.bundesliga.com/en/tournaments/news/2013/0000262446.php|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106163106/http://www.bundesliga.com/en/tournaments/news/2013/0000262446.php|archive-date=6 November 2013}} The 2013–14 season started with a five-game winning streak for Dortmund, their best start to a season. Despite such a promising start, however, their season was hampered by injuries to several key players, seeing them stoop as low as fourth place in the table, and with a depleted squad could go only as far as the quarter-finals of the [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]], losing 3–2 on aggregate to [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]. Nevertheless, Dortmund managed to end their season on a high note by finishing second in the Bundesliga and reaching the [[2014 DFB-Pokal Final]], losing 0–2 to Bayern in extra time.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfb.de/index.php?id=512870&action=showDay&lang=E&liga=dfbpokm&saison=13&saisonl=2013&spieltag=6&cHash=6384bccaf405c978a3b249f186aa143a|title=Final}} They then began their [[2014–15 Bundesliga|2014–15 season]] by defeating Bayern in the [[2014 DFL-Supercup]] 2–0. After the eighth matchday, they were surpassed by Bayern Munich following an unlucky draw with [[TSG 1899 Hoffenheim|1899 Hoffenheim]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/33541336|title=B Dortmund 4–0 B Mgladbach|work=BBC Sport|access-date=8 August 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/spieltag/1-bundesliga/2015-16/6/2854984/spielanalyse_1899-hoffenheim-3209_borussia-dortmund-17.html|title=Verflixte 12! Rudy beendet Dortmunds starke Serie: TSG Hoffenheim – Borussia Dortmund 1:1 (1:0)|website=kicker online|access-date=8 August 2016}} Dortmund kept their performances up, winning 24 out of 34 league games and becoming the best Bundesliga runner-up team of all time.{{Cite web|url=http://www.90min.com/de/posts/2956063-borussia-dortmund-der-beste-zweitplatzierte-aller-zeiten-platz-eins-unerreichbar|title=Borussia Dortmund: Der beste Zweitplatzierte aller Zeiten – Platz eins unerreichbar?|date=15 February 2016|access-date=8 August 2016}} In the [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]], they advanced to the quarter-finals, getting knocked out by a Jürgen Klopp-led [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in a dramatic comeback at [[Anfield]], where defender [[Dejan Lovren]] scored a late goal to make it 4–3 to the Reds and 5–4 on aggregate.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/14/liverpool-borussia-dortmund-europa-league-report|title=Liverpool's Lovren sinks Borussia Dortmund in remarkable comeback|last=Anfield|first=Andy Hunter at|date=15 April 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|issn=0261-3077|access-date=8 August 2016}} In the [[2015–16 DFB-Pokal]], for the third-straight year Dortmund made it to the competition [[2016 DFB-Pokal Final|final]], but lost to Bayern Munich on penalties.{{Cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/sport/2016-05/fc-bayern-gewinnt-das-dfb-pokalfinale-in-berlin|title=DFB-Pokal: Bayern holen Pokalsieg im Elfmeterschießen|date=22 May 2016|newspaper=Die Zeit|issn=0044-2070|access-date=8 August 2016}} On 11 April 2017, [[Borussia Dortmund team bus bombing|three explosions occurred near the team's bus]] on its way to a [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] match against [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] at the [[Westfalenstadion|Signal Iduna Park]]. Defender [[Marc Bartra]] was injured, and taken to hospital.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-39571776|title=Borussia Dortmund football team bus hit by explosions|date=11 April 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=11 April 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.com/uefa-champions-league/story/3101531/one-hurt-in-explosion-near-borussia-dortmund-team-bus|title=Marc Bartra hurt in explosions near Dortmund team bus, game postponed|work=ESPNFC.com|date=11 April 2017|access-date=11 April 2017}} Dortmund went on to lose the game 2–3 to AS Monaco. Dortmund's manager, [[Thomas Tuchel]], blamed the loss as a result of an ignorant decision by [[UEFA]]. UEFA went on to say that the team made no objection to playing, and that the decision was made in compliance with the club and local law enforcement.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39582284|title=Borussia Dortmund: Thomas Tuchel says club 'ignored' over Monaco tie|date=12 April 2017|work=BBC Sport|access-date=12 April 2017}} In the second leg, Dortmund went on to lose 1–3, leaving the aggregate score at 3–6, and seeing them eliminated from that year's UEFA Champions League. On 26 April, Dortmund defeated [[Bayern Munich]] 3–2 in Munich to advance to the [[2017 DFB-Pokal Final]], Dortmund's fourth consecutive final and fifth in six seasons. On 27 May, Dortmund won the [[2016–17 DFB-Pokal]] 2–1 over [[Eintracht Frankfurt]] with the winner coming from a penalty converted by [[Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39909511 |title=Eintracht Frankfurt 1–2 Borussia Dortmund |work=BBC Sport |date=27 May 2017 |access-date=14 May 2021}} Ahead of the 2017–18 season, Thomas Tuchel stepped down as manager. |publisher=Bundesliga |access-date=14 May 2021}} Michy Batshuayi also returned to Chelsea. In the summer of 2018, Dortmund appointed former [[OGC Nice]] coach, [[Lucien Favre]] as their manager/head coach. After a very busy transfer window for the team, seeing eight new players arrive at the club for the first team squad, Dortmund performed strongly, chasing [[Bayern Munich]] for the title race down to the last matchday, narrowly missing out on the league title by two points and earning Lucien Favre a contract extension. A four-part [[Amazon Prime Video]] documentary series was created, about the same season, named "Inside Borussia Dortmund". The next season, Dortmund pulled off a few big-name signings with the intent of winning the Bundesliga title. Although they won the DFL Supercup, this was their only silverware this season. After a scrappy first half of the season, they changed their tactics and made a few more transfers in the January Window. They were eliminated in both the DFB-Pokal and the UEFA Champions League as well. Due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Germany]], the season stopped abruptly. Once the restart occurred, Dortmund looked better but their performances were not enough to stop a dominant Bayern Munich side from grasping the Bundesliga title. They finished the 2019–20 season in second place after beating [[RB Leipzig]] in matchweek 33 due to a brace from [[Erling Haaland]]. Dortmund got off to a rather shaky start in the 2020–21 season. They lost the DFL-Supercup and had an inconsistent set of results in the Champions League and the Bundesliga. After a humiliating 5–1 defeat to Stuttgart in Matchday 11, Lucien Favre was relieved of his managerial duties. Assistant manager [[Edin Terzić (footballer)|Edin Terzić]] was placed as the caretaker for the rest of the season. Under Terzić, Dortmund finished third on the final matchday of the Bundesliga and was eliminated in the quarter-finals of the Champions League in a clash against Manchester City. The team then managed to win the DFB-Pokal, [[2021 DFB-Pokal Final|defeating RB Leipzig 4–1 in the final]]. Marco Rose was appointed manager for the 2021–22 season with Terzić being appointed as the club's new technical director.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bvb.de/eng/News/Overview/Terzic-I-can-hardly-wait-to-get-started|title = Terzic: ''I can hardly wait to get started''}} ==Crest== File:Logo Borussia Dortmund (1945-1964).svg|1945–1964 File:Logo Borussia Dortmund 1964 - 1974.gif|1964–1974 File:Logo Borussia Dortmund 1974 - 1976.gif|1974–1976 and 1978–1993 File:Borussia Dortmund logo.svg|1993–present File:Borussia Dortmund.svg|2012–present ==Grounds== {{Main|Westfalenstadion|Stadion Rote Erde}} [[File:Signal iduna park stadium dortmund 4.jpg|thumb|right|[[Westfalenstadion|Signal Iduna Park]] is the biggest stadium in Germany]] [[File:Borusseum.jpg|thumb|right|The ''Borusseum'', a museum about Borussia Dortmund]] ===Stadiums=== The Westfalenstadion is the home stadium of Borussia Dortmund, Germany's largest stadium and the seventh-largest in Europe.This includes standing terraces used for [[Bundesliga]] matches. The all-seated capacity is not the largest in Germany; that distinction is held by the [[Olympic Stadium (Berlin)|Olympic Stadium]] in [[Berlin]]. The stadium is officially named "Signal Iduna Park" after insurance company [[Signal Iduna]] purchased the rights to name the stadium until 2021.{{cite web |title= Borussia Dortmund und Signal Iduna verlängern Zusammenarbeit bis 2021 |url= http://aktie.bvb.de/IR-News/Corporate-News/Borussia-Dortmund-und-Signal-Iduna-verlaengern-Zusammenarbeit-bis-2021 |publisher= aktie.bvb.de |access-date= 23 July 2013 |language= de}} This name, however, cannot be used when hosting [[FIFA]] and [[UEFA]] events, since these governing bodies have policies forbidding corporate sponsorship from companies that are not official tournament partners. During the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]], the stadium was referred to as "FIFA World Cup Stadium, Dortmund", while in UEFA club matches, it is known as "BVB Stadion Dortmund". The stadium currently hosts up to 81,359 spectators (standing and seated) for league matches and 65,829 seated spectators for international matches.{{cite web |url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/630989/artikel_dortmunds-stadionkapazitaet-erhoeht-sich.html |title=Dortmunds Stadionkapazität erhöht sich |language=de |date=16 July 2015 |publisher=Kicker |access-date=17 July 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.stadionwelt.de/sw_stadien/index.php?folder=sites&site=stadionguide_d&id=172 |title=SIGNAL IDUNA PARK, Borussia Dortmund |language=de |publisher=stadionwelt.de |access-date=26 July 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151127005809/http://www.stadionwelt.de/sw_stadien/index.php?folder=sites&site=stadionguide_d&id=172 |archive-date=27 November 2015 |url-status=dead }} For these, the characteristic southern grandstand is re-equipped with seats to conform to FIFA regulations. In 1974, the Westfalenstadion replaced the [[Stadion Rote Erde]], which is located next door and serves now as the stadium of [[Borussia Dortmund II]]. After the increasing popularity of Borussia Dortmund in the 1960s, it became obvious that the traditional ground was too small for the increasing number of Borussia Dortmund supporters. The city of Dortmund, however, was not able to finance a new stadium and federal institutions were unwilling to help. But in 1971, Dortmund was selected to replace the city of [[Cologne]], which was forced to withdraw its plans to host games in the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974 World Cup]]. The funds originally set aside for the projected stadium in Cologne were thus re-allocated to Dortmund, and a new stadium became reality. The Westfalenstadion has undergone several renovations throughout the years to increase the size of the stadium, including an expansion of the stadium for the 2006 World Cup. In 2008, the ''Borusseum'', a museum about Borussia Dortmund, opened in the stadium.{{Cite web|url=https://www.krafthaus.eu/en/borusseum-bvb-dortmund-09-football-museum/|title=Borusseum –BVB Dortmund 09 Football Museum |language=en-GB|access-date=6 December 2019 | website = krafthaus.eu}} In 2011, Borussia Dortmund agreed to a partnership with [[Q-Cells]]. The company installed 8,768 [[solar cell]]s on the roof of the Westfalenstadion to generate up to 860,000 [[Kilowatt hour|kWh]] per year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pv-tech.org/news/q_cells_signs_sponsorship_deal_with_borussia_dortmund|title=Q-Cells signs sponsorship deal with Borussia Dortmund|website=PV Tech|date=15 July 2011|language=en|access-date=6 December 2019}} Borussia Dortmund has the highest average attendance of any [[Football club (association football)|football club]] worldwide.{{Cite web|url=http://billsportsmaps.com/?p=22541|title=2011-12 World Football Attendances – Best Drawing Leagues (Chart of Top-20-drawing national leagues of association football) / Plus list of 35-highest drawing association football clubs in the world in 2011-12. " billsportsmaps.com}} In 2014, it was estimated that each of the club's home games is attended by around 1,000 British spectators, drawn to the team by its low ticket prices compared to the [[Premier League]].{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Ben|title=Price of Football 2014: Why fans flock to Borussia Dortmund|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29624410|access-date=1 November 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=15 October 2014}} ===Training ground=== Borussia Dortmund's [[Training ground (association football)|training ground]] and [[Football academy|Academy]] base ''Hohenbuschei'' is located in Brackel, a district of Dortmund.{{cite web |url=https://www.derwesten.de/staedte/dortmund/bvb-trainingszentrum-in-dortmund-brackel-am-hohenbuschei-eroeffnet-id4511839.html |title=BVB-Trainingszentrum in Dortmund-Brackel am Hohenbuschei eröffnet |date=6 April 2011 |publisher=Der Westen |language=de |access-date=6 April 2011}} Inside the complex, there are [[physical exercise]] training for [[physical fitness]] and [[rehabilitation robotics]] areas, [[physiotherapy]] and massage rooms, and remedial and [[hydrotherapy pool]]s. There are also [[sauna]] rooms, [[steam room]]s and [[weight room]]s, classrooms, [[conference hall]]s, offices for the BVB [[Front office (sports)|front office]], a restaurant, and a TV studio to [[interview]] the BVB [[professional footballer]]s and [[coaching staff]] for ''BVB total!'', the channel owned by the club.{{cite web |url=http://www.bvb.de/ger/content/view/full/48021 |title=Trainingszentrum wird eingeweiht Borussia zieht nach Brackel um |publisher=Borussia Dortmund |language=de |access-date=10 June 2018}} On the grounds, there are five grass [[Pitch (sports field)|pitches]], two of which have [[under-soil heating]], one [[Artificial turf|artificial grass field]], three small [[Sports turf|grass]] pitches and a multi-functional [[sports arena]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ruhrnachrichten.de/Staedte/Dortmund/Startschuss-ist-gefallen-Trainingszentrum-wird-erweitert-873948.html |title=Startschuss ist gefallen – Trainingszentrum wird erweitert |publisher=Ruhr Nachrichten |language=de |access-date=18 June 2010}} The site covers a total area of {{convert|18000|m2|abbr=on}}. In addition, the club owns a ''Footbonaut'', a training [[robot]] which is effectively a {{convert|14|m2|abbr=on}} training cage.{{cite web |url=http://www.dfb.de/news/detail/footbonaut-der-kreativitaet-sind-keine-grenzen-gesetzt-139204/ |title=Footbonaut: "Der Kreativität sind keine Grenzen gesetzt" |publisher=Deutscher Fußball-Bund |language=de |access-date=10 June 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbox.com/blog/borussia-dortmund-football-training-robot/ |title=The Future of Sport: Borussia Dortmund Football Training Robot |publisher=Soccer Box |access-date=10 June 2018}} The training complex and youth performance centre, located in Hohenbuschei, will be expanded in stages until 2021. In addition, the ''Sports Business Office'' will be entirely rebuilt from scratch. The planned construction, which will cost up to 20 million euros, will make BVB the best-equipped [[Football club (association football)|football club]] in the country with regards to infrastructure.{{cite web |url=https://www.bvb.de/eng/News/Overview/We-re-building-Borussia-s-future |title=We're building Borussia's future |publisher=Borussia Dortmund |access-date=30 June 2019}} In the ''Strobelallee Training Centre'', the BVB Evonik Football Academy has an outstanding training venue exclusively at its disposal. Among others, the Bundesliga-team used to prepare for their matches on the club's former training ground.{{cite web |url=https://www.bvb.de/eng/BVB/Football-Academy/Info/Strobelallee-Training-Centre |title=Strobelallee Training Centre |publisher=Borussia Dortmund |access-date=1 July 2019}} ==Organisation and finance== Borussia Dortmund [[Eingetragener Verein|e.V.]] is represented by its management board and a [[board of directors]] consisting of [[president (corporate title)|president]] Dr. [[Reinhard Rauball]], his proxy and [[vice-president]] Gerd Pieper, and [[treasurer]] Dr. Reinhold Lunow.{{cite web|url= http://www.bvb.de/Der-Verein|title= Der Verein|language= de|trans-title= The Club|website=bvb.de|publisher= BVB|access-date= 18 April 2014}} Professional football at Dortmund is run by the organisation Borussia Dortmund [[Kommanditgesellschaft auf Aktien#Germany|GmbH & Co. KGaA]]. This corporation model has two types of participators: at least one partner with [[unlimited liability]] and at least one partner with [[limited liability]]. The investment of the latter is divided into [[stock]]s. KGaA. Borussia Dortmund GmbH is fully owned by the sports club, Borussia Dortmund e.V. This organizational structure was designed to ensure that the sports club has full control over the professional squad.{{cite web|url=http://aktie.bvb.de/BVB-auf-einen-Blick/Unternehmensportrait |title=Unternehmensportrait / BVB auf einen Blick / BVB Aktie |language=de |publisher=Aktie.bvb.de |access-date=27 August 2013}} The [[stock]] of Borussia Dortmund GmbH & Co. KGaA became the first and so far the only publicly traded [[sports club]] on the German stock market. 5.53% of Borussia Dortmund GmbH & Co. KGaA is owned by the sports club, Borussia Dortmund e.V.; 9.33% by Bernd Geske; and 59.93% widely spread [[Shareholder|shareholdings]].{{cite web |title=Shareholder Structure |url=http://aktie.bvb.de/eng/BVB-Share/Shareholder-Structure |publisher=aktie.bvb.de |access-date=9 March 2019}} Hans-Joachim Watzke is the [[chief executive officer|CEO]] and Thomas Treß is the [[chief financial officer|CFO]] of the GmbH & Co. [[Michael Zorc]] as [[Director of football|sporting director]] is responsible for the first team, the [[coaching staff]], the youth and junior section, and [[Scout (sport)|scouting]].{{cite web |title=Organisation and Management |url=http://aktie.bvb.de/eng/BVB-at-a-glance/Organisation-and-Management2 |publisher=aktie.bvb.de |access-date=23 July 2013}} The [[supervisory board]] consists, among others, of politicians [[Werner Müller (politician)|Werner Müller]] and [[Peer Steinbrück]].{{cite web |title=Supervisory Board |url=http://aktie.bvb.de/eng/BVB-at-a-glance/Supervisory-Board |publisher=aktie.bvb.de |access-date=23 July 2013}} Borussia Dortmund e.V. and Borussia Dortmund GmbH & Co. In 1966, [[Willi Multhaup]] led his side to the [[1965–66 European Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup]], the first German team to win a European trophy. [[Horst Köppel]] was the coach to bring major silverware to the club for the first time in over 20 years, winning the [[1988–89 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]] in 1989. [[Ottmar Hitzfeld]] is the club's most successful coach, having won both the Bundesliga and [[DFL-Supercup|Supercup]] twice. In [[1996–97 UEFA Champions League|1997]], Dortmund had waited for continental success for over 30 years; Hitzfeld crowned his period with an unexpected triumph and won the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]]. Dortmund won the [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]] in [[1997 Intercontinental Cup|1997]] and head coach [[Nevio Scala]] became the first and so far the only non-native speaker who won a major title. In [[2001–02 Bundesliga|2001–02]], [[Matthias Sammer]], a former BVB player, brought the league title back to Dortmund. In [[2008–09 Bundesliga|2008–09]], the club approached [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz 05]] head coach [[Jürgen Klopp]]. He won the club's seventh championship title in [[2010–11 Bundesliga|2010–11]]. In his [[2011–12 Borussia Dortmund season|fourth season]], Dortmund won the [[2011–12 Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] and the [[2011–12 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]] to complete the first league and cup [[Double (association football)|double]] in the club's history.{{cite web |title=Dortmund at the Double: history in the making in 2012 |url= https://www.bvb.de/eng/News/Overview/BVB-rewrote-history-in-2012-with-stunning-cup-final-win |publisher=Borussia Dortmund |access-date= 27 January 2016}} Successor [[Thomas Tuchel]] won the [[2016–17 DFB-Pokal]].
